I disagree on the logic. Maybe most people are not able to hold two conflicting ideas as equal, and I am wrong.

 While you may or may not agree with logic, your (dis)agreement does not change what is.
 
 Consider this: a square is defined as a shape with four sides of equal length connected at perpindicular angles. Person A observes the square and labels it a square. Person B observes the square, but labels the shape a circle. Assuming a world of physical reality, Person B is incorrect. Here we have an example of two opposing ideas that contradict. They cannot both be true in the physical world.
 
 A literal interpretation of the bible dictates that the earth was created in six 24-hour periods less than 10,000 years ago. This contradicts observed phenomena in the physical world. They both cannot be true in the physical world.
 
 
Also why would anyone hold genesis litterally?

 Good question. I'm sure there are plenty of reasons. Ask around.
 
 If you are suggesting that both a non-literal interpretation of the bible and science can potentially both be objectively true, then you are correct. But then there are no opposing ideas. In other words, a non-literal interpretation of the bible does not contradict science.
 
 You asked the question:
 
"How come you can't believe two opposing ideas as true?"

 Logically, if the truth of conclusion A precludes conclusion B from being true and vice-versa, then they cannot both be true. If the truth of conclusion A does not preclude the truth of conclusion B, then they are not really opposing ideas.

 Actually I think that XQ is confused by a standare creationist argument. Here it is to the best of my ability.
 
 When it is pointed out that there are objects that are very, very far from earth, and that the light from those objects is just now reaching earth, creationists sometimes propose that the universe and the earth were created with the appearance of great age. Light from distant stars was created on the way to earth without having been emited from the star. In other words, anything that indicates that the earth or the universe is old was created by god to appear so - as a test of faith we are told.
 
 This is known as lastthursdayism. If the above is possibly true, then it is also possible that the universe was created with aparent history last Thursday. Of course, since you remember events from last Wednesday and before, these memories were also created by an omnipotent god.
 
 The problem is that this view makes god a liar. What about a supernova that occurred about 170,000 years ago and that was visible on earth only in 1987? Did god create the history of the event even thought it never happened? Doesn't that make god a liar?

Well, that's true but it doesn't bother creationists. When it is pointed out to them that there is no trace of the flood on the pyramids and that Egyptian history is silent about the flood, their answer is that of course the history wouldn't record the flood. Everyone was killed.
 
 But if the flood occurred about 4500 years ago as creationists claim, that was the period of pyramid building in Egypt. So creationists claim that the Egyptian culture has been misdated. But if that were the case, where did enough people to build the pyramids come from? It would have necessarily taken more years than are available for the population to grow from 8 to millions.
 
 By the way, Last-Thursdayism says that the history and the memories of the people were created by an all powerful god. It doesn't matter if you think that Egypt was older than the creation. That history was created in place, just as light was created in transit from distant stars (not yet created).
